   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also has been on vanc/zosyn for
   the last 9 days so new HAP would be unlikely.  However, VRE, fungal or
   other ESBL organism is a possibility. No cough or fever for the last 24
   hours.  Currently appears tachypneic and uncomfortable. KUB yesterday
   also showed severe ascites, but patient's abdomen at this time appears
   to be predominantly distended from abdominal gas, likely a result of
   lactulose administration.  Bladder pressures have been relatively
   stable in the high teens.   Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming
   more somnolent, able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved
   somewhat with Narcan.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema
   - Likely needs to be intubated, but will monitor with ABG for worsening
   hypoxemia and hypercarbia
   - Avoid narcotics
   - Repeat bladder pressure
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   - Would be helpful to get sputum sample though patient is not likely to
   cooperate with this.  Will treat for multifocal pna with vanc/zosyn as
   this likely was a new event/infiltrate.  [**Month (only) 11**] need to consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improved after albumin infusion (x3), which
   argued against HRS.  Cr had normalized x 5 days but again elevated on
   [**3-23**] and is increasing.  HRS treatment was discontinued and has been
   restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue albumin for likely intravascular volume depletion and HRS
   - Continue octreotide , increase midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Continue lactulose and rifaxamin (stooling well)
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   .
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] and Cipro started to complete
   total 2 week abd course. No growth on culture of peritoneal fluid.
   Bladder pressure elevated on morning of [**3-20**], pt increasingly
   uncomfortable and dyspneic. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to remove 2.5L
   grossly bloody fluid. Required increasing pain meds [**Date range (1) 5037**] but d/c
   [**3-23**] because no longer complaining of pain.
   - Restarted vanc/Zosyn, but will switch to Cipro after PNA resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure today with goal < 20mmHg
   .
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   .
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   .
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. On ciprofloxacin.
   Foley changed overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**]. Will follow up on culture and adjust
   abx as needed.  Repeat culture growing yeast.
   - Continue cipro
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient continues to decompensate,
   though no positive blood cultures
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   .
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Decreased D5W to 50cc/hr
   .
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   .
   # FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS
   .
   Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and
   thrombocytopenia), PPI
   .
   Access: PIV, PICC (placed [**3-19**])
   .
   Code: Full code.  Ongoing discussion between liver team, MICU team and
   family given patient's declining status. Will discuss intubation today,
   although not certain it will happen.
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcohol abuse and Tylenol overuse, who was transferred back to the ICU with worsening renal function, mental status, and respiratory distress. She has a history of liver failure, portal vein thrombosis, and hyperbilirubinemia. The patient has been experiencing acute renal failure, with a recent increase in creatinine levels. She also has altered mental status, likely due to hepatic encephalopathy and hypernatremia.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including vanc/zosyn, ciprofloxacin, and rifaxamin, and has had several diagnostic procedures, including a CT scan and diagnostic paracentesis. She has been experiencing worsening hypoxia, with a recent CXR showing a new infiltrate, and has been treated with narcan and oxygen therapy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Hypoxia: The patient's worsening hypoxia is a concern, and she may require intubation to ensure adequate oxygenation.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's recent increase in creatinine levels is a concern, and she may require further treatment to address this complication.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to hepatic encephalopathy, and she may require further treatment to address this complication.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is a concern, and she may require further treatment to address this complication.
5. UTI: The patient's positive U/A and culture growing yeast are a concern, and she may require further treatment to address this complication.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is a concern, and she may require further treatment to address this complication.
7. Portal vein thrombosis: The patient's portal vein thrombosis is a concern, and she may require further treatment to address this complication.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's oxygenation and respiratory status, and consider intubation if necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as necessary.
3. Continue to treat the patient's hepatic encephalopathy and hypernatremia.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's UTI and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's portal vein thrombosis and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Consider consulting with a liver specialist to discuss the patient's prognosis and likelihood of recovery.

   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also has been on vanc/zosyn for
   the last 9 days so new HAP would be unlikely.  However, VRE, fungal or
   other ESBL organism is a possibility. No cough or fever for the last 24
   hours.  Currently appears tachypneic and uncomfortable. KUB yesterday
   also showed severe ascites, but patient's abdomen at this time appears
   to be predominantly distended from abdominal gas, likely a result of
   lactulose administration.  Bladder pressures have been relatively
   stable in the high teens.   Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming
   more somnolent, able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved
   somewhat with Narcan.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema
   - Likely needs to be intubated, but will monitor with ABG for worsening
   hypoxemia and hypercarbia
   - Avoid narcotics
   - Repeat bladder pressure
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   - Would be helpful to get sputum sample though patient is not likely to
   cooperate with this.  Will treat for multifocal pna with vanc/zosyn as
   this likely was a new event/infiltrate.  [**Month (only) 11**] need to consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improved after albumin infusion (x3), which
   argued against HRS.  Cr had normalized x 5 days but again elevated on
   [**3-23**] and is increasing.  HRS treatment was discontinued and has been
   restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue albumin for likely intravascular volume depletion and HRS
   - Continue octreotide , increase midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Continue lactulose and rifaxamin (stooling well)
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   .
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] and Cipro started to complete
   total 2 week abd course. No growth on culture of peritoneal fluid.
   Bladder pressure elevated on morning of [**3-20**], pt increasingly
   uncomfortable and dyspneic. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to remove 2.5L
   grossly bloody fluid. Required increasing pain meds [**Date range (1) 5037**] but d/c
   [**3-23**] because no longer complaining of pain.
   - Restarted vanc/Zosyn, but will switch to Cipro after PNA resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure today with goal < 20mmHg
   .
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   .
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   .
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. On ciprofloxacin.
   Foley changed overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**]. Will follow up on culture and adjust
   abx as needed.  Repeat culture growing yeast.
   - Continue cipro
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient continues to decompensate,
   though no positive blood cultures
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   .
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Decreased D5W to 50cc/hr
   .
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   .
   # FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS
   .
   Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and
   thrombocytopenia), PPI
   .
   Access: PIV, PICC (placed [**3-19**])
   .
   Code: Full code.  Ongoing discussion between liver team, MICU team and
   family given patient's declining status. Will discuss intubation today,

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcohol abuse and Tylenol overuse, who is status post a 2-week stay in the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental status, and respiratory distress.

The patient has several potential medical complications:

1. Hypoxia: The patient has a CXR with possible multifocal pneumonia, and is at risk for further respiratory decline. The patient's oxygen requirement has decreased since receiving Narcan, but they still require supplemental oxygen. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.31, which is slightly acidic.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has trended upwards, and the patient has a FENa of less than 1%, suggesting pre-renal azotemia due to hypovolemia or hepatorenal syndrome. The patient has been receiving albumin infusions, which have improved their renal function.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient has a history of liver encephalopathy and SBP, and is currently altered and responsive to voice. The patient's hypernatremia is likely contributing to their altered mental status.
4. SBP: The patient has a history of SBP, and has received antibiotics and paracentesis. The patient's bladder pressure is elevated, and they require increasing pain medication.
5. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, and has received aggressive FFP transfusions. The patient's anemia is likely multifactorial, with contributions from intrabdominal bleeding, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease.
6. Cirrhosis/Hyperbilirubinemia/Portal Vein Thrombosis: The patient has cirrhosis, hyperbilirubinemia, and portal vein thrombosis, which is likely secondary to cirrhosis from alcoholism and chronic acetaminophen use.
7. UTI: The patient has a positive U/A, and is currently receiving ciprofloxacin. The patient's culture is growing yeast, and they may require antifungal treatment.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which is likely secondary to liver failure and splenomegaly. The patient's platelet count has improved, and they may require further transfusions.
9. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which is likely due to transudative fluid accumulation in the ascites and LE edema. The patient's hypernatremia is being treated with free water flushes and decreased D5W infusion.
10. FEN: The patient has a FEN of IVF, and is receiving repletion of electrolytes and TF per nutrition recommendations.

Based on the patient's condition, the following potential medical complications are at risk:

* Further respiratory decline
* Renal failure
* Liver failure
* Infection
* Bleeding
* Thrombosis

The patient's code status is full code, and the patient's family is being informed of their declining status. The patient's disposition is uncertain, and further discussion is needed between the liver team, MICU team, and family regarding the patient's prognosis and likelihood of recovery.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's condition remains critical with ongoing respiratory failure, acute pain, and hypernatremia. Notable changes include:

* Increased midodrine to 5mg TID as recommended by hepatology
* Bladder pressure remains elevated at 22 mmHg, which may indicate ongoing bladder distension or obstruction
* Family meeting held to discuss potential intubation if necessary
* FIO2 weaned from 100% to 60%, indicating some improvement in oxygenation
* Lanthanum started due to increasing PO4 levels
* IV fluids increased to 100 cc/hr to address hypernatremia

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: progression to ARDS, worsening hypoxemia, or respiratory arrest
* Hypernatremia: seizures, coma, or death due to electrolyte imbalance
* Bladder pressure: bladder rupture, urinary tract infections, or chronic bladder damage
* Coagulopathy: bleeding complications, including intracranial hemorrhage or gastrointestinal bleeding
* Anemia: worsening anemia, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues
* Hepatorenal syndrome: worsening kidney function, leading to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease
* Impaired skin integrity: increased risk of skin breakdown, pressure ulcers, or infections

The patient's lab results indicate ongoing liver dysfunction, coagulopathy, and electrolyte imbalance. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows stable vital signs, but the patient's condition remains critical. Further monitoring and management are necessary to address these complications and prevent further deterioration.

Summary:

The patient is a 44-year-old female with a history of cirrhosis, admitted with decompensated liver failure likely triggered by EtOH and Tylenol ingestion. She has ongoing issues of altered mental status, renal failure, and coagulopathy with blood loss anemia. She was unable to stay on the medical floor due to worsening mental status and tachypnea, and was returned to the ICU for further care.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, and blood pressure of 121/64 mmHg. She has a SpO2 of 96% on 50% FiO2, and her ABG results are 7.31/60/198/30/2.

The patient's physical examination reveals asterixis, jaundice, and extreme lethargy. She has a soft, distended abdomen, and her extremities are edematous. Her laboratory results show worsening renal failure, coagulopathy, and liver dysfunction.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Altered mental status: increasing lactulose and considering intubation
* Acute respiratory failure: continuing Vancomycin and Zosyn, and considering intubation
* Hepato-Renal Syndrome/Acute Renal Failure: continuing midodrine, octreotide, and albumin
* Coagulopathy: monitoring HCT and considering transfusions
* Very poor prognosis: discussing goals of care with the family and considering full code status

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis: given the patient's history of cirrhosis and liver failure, she may be at risk for sepsis, which could worsen her condition.
* Respiratory failure: the patient's acute respiratory failure may progress to respiratory arrest, which could be life-threatening.
* Cardiac complications: the patient's coagulopathy and liver dysfunction may increase her risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
* Infection: the patient's compromised immune system and prolonged hospitalization may increase her risk of infection, which could worsen her condition.
* Bleeding: the patient's coagulopathy and liver dysfunction may increase her risk of bleeding, which could be life-threatening.
* Renal failure: the patient's worsening renal failure may progress to end-stage renal disease, which could require dialysis.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also completed 9 days of
   vanc/zosyn for SBP thus it would be unlikely that pt developed a new
   PNA. However, VRE, fungal or other ESBL organism is a possibility. Her
   abdominal girth may also be contributing to decreased chest wall
   compliance. Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming more somnolent,
   able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved somewhat with
   Narcan. Satting in mid-90s on 4-5L O2 NC this morning.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema; will treat with
   Vanc/Zosyn again as this was a new event/infiltrate. Consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   - Will try to avoid intubation as it will likely be very difficult to
   extubated; however OK to intubate if necessary per family.
   - Avoid narcotics (none given since [**3-24**])
   - Repeat bladder pressure (15 this morning)
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improves after albumin infusion (5 infusions
   of 75g each so far), which argues against HRS. HRS treatment was
   discontinued and has been restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue octreotide, midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Increase lactulose and continue rifaxamin; quantify stool output to
   monitor response
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Also added Vanc. Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] with
   intention of switching to Cipro, however given new infiltrate on CXR
   along with increasing resp distress Vanc and Zosyn were re-started. No
   growth on culture of peritoneal fluid. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to
   remove 2.5L grossly bloody fluid.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn for now, but will switch to Cipro after PNA
   resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. Foley changed
   overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**].
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient decompensates, though no
   positive blood cultures
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Continue D5W at 100cc/hr for now, recheck lytes in afternoon.
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   # FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS
   Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and
   thrombocytopenia), PPI

   family given patient's declining status. Poor prognosis.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also completed 9 days of
   vanc/zosyn for SBP thus it would be unlikely that pt developed a new
   PNA. However, VRE, fungal or other ESBL organism is a possibility. Her
   abdominal girth may also be contributing to decreased chest wall
   compliance. Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming more somnolent,
   able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved somewhat with
   Narcan. Satting in mid-90s on 4-5L O2 NC this morning.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema; will treat with
   Vanc/Zosyn again as this was a new event/infiltrate. Consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   - Will try to avoid intubation as it will likely be very difficult to
   extubated; however OK to intubate if necessary per family.
   - Avoid narcotics (none given since [**3-24**])
   - Repeat bladder pressure (15 this morning)
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improves after albumin infusion (5 infusions
   of 75g each so far), which argues against HRS. HRS treatment was
   discontinued and has been restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue octreotide, midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Increase lactulose and continue rifaxamin; quantify stool output to
   monitor response
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Also added Vanc. Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] with
   intention of switching to Cipro, however given new infiltrate on CXR
   along with increasing resp distress Vanc and Zosyn were re-started. No
   growth on culture of peritoneal fluid. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to
   remove 2.5L grossly bloody fluid.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn for now, but will switch to Cipro after PNA
   resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. Foley changed
   overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**].
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient decompensates, though no
   positive blood cultures
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.

   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely

Summary:

The patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcohol abuse and Tylenol overuse, who is status post a 2-week stay in the MICU and has been transferred back to the ICU with worsening renal function, mental status, and respiratory distress. The patient has a history of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), and has received treatment with piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) and vancomycin. The patient's current conditions include:

* Hypoxia: The patient has a new infiltrate on CXR and is requiring increased oxygen support. The patient is also at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine has trended up to 3.0, and the patient has a high FENa, indicating pre-renal azotemia due to hypovolemia or hepatorenal syndrome.
* Altered mental status: The patient has a history of hepatic encephalopathy and SBP, and is currently persistently hypernatremic.
* SBP: The patient has a history of SBP and has received treatment with Zosyn and vancomycin.
* Anemia: The patient has a stable anemia, likely due to multifactorial causes, including intrabdominal bleeding, low-grade GI bleed, and anemia of chronic disease.
* Cirrhosis: The patient has cirrhosis, likely secondary to alcoholism, with exacerbation from chronic acetaminophen use.
* Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient has elevated bilirubin levels, likely due to cirrhosis and portal vein thrombosis.
* Portal vein thrombosis: The patient has acute portal vein thrombosis, likely due to cirrhosis and liver failure.
* UTI: The patient has a positive urine culture, growing yeast.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient has improved thrombocytopenia, likely due to liver failure and splenomegaly.
* Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, likely due to TF and ascites.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening hypoxia and infiltrate on CXR increase the risk of respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's history of SBP and current positive urine culture increase the risk of sepsis.
* Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's persistently hypernatremic and altered mental status increase the risk of hepatic encephalopathy.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's pre-renal azotemia and high FENa increase the risk of acute kidney injury.
* GI bleeding: The patient's history of low-grade GI bleed and anemia of chronic disease increase the risk of GI bleeding.
* Portal hypertension: The patient's cirrhosis and portal vein thrombosis increase the risk of portal hypertension.
* Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis and portal vein thrombosis increase the risk of liver failure.
* Infection: The patient's positive urine culture and history of SBP increase the risk of infection.

Recommendations:

* Continue treatment with Zosyn and vancomycin for SBP.
* Re-start Cipro after PNA resolves.
* Continue lactulose and rifaxamin for hepatic encephalopathy.
* Increase lactulose and rifaxamin as needed to monitor response.
* Continue midodrine and octreotide for portal hypertension and liver failure.
* Follow liver enzymes and bilirubin levels.
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and infection.
* Continue to monitor for respiratory failure and consider intubation if necessary.
* Continue to monitor for GI bleeding and consider endoscopy if necessary.
* Consider antifungal treatment if patient decompensates.
* Continue to monitor for thrombocytopenia and consider platelet transfusions if necessary.
* Continue to monitor for hypernatremia and consider treatment as necessary.

   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also completed 9 days of
   vanc/zosyn for SBP thus it would be unlikely that pt developed a new
   PNA. However, VRE, fungal or other ESBL organism is a possibility. Her
   abdominal girth may also be contributing to decreased chest wall
   compliance. Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming more somnolent,
   able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved somewhat with
   Narcan. Satting in mid-90s on 4-5L O2 NC this morning.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema; will treat with
   Vanc/Zosyn again as this was a new event/infiltrate. Consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   - Will try to avoid intubation as it will likely be very difficult to
   extubated; however OK to intubate if necessary per family.
   - Avoid narcotics (none given since [**3-24**])
   - Repeat bladder pressure (15 this morning)
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improves after albumin infusion (5 infusions
   of 75g each so far), which argues against HRS. HRS treatment was
   discontinued and has been restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue octreotide, midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Increase lactulose and continue rifaxamin; quantify stool output to
   monitor response
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Also added Vanc. Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] with
   intention of switching to Cipro, however given new infiltrate on CXR
   along with increasing resp distress Vanc and Zosyn were re-started. No
   growth on culture of peritoneal fluid. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to
   remove 2.5L grossly bloody fluid.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn for now, but will switch to Cipro after PNA
   resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. Foley changed
   overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**].
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient decompensates, though no
   positive blood cultures
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Continue D5W at 100cc/hr for now, recheck lytes in afternoon.
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   # FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS
   Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and
   thrombocytopenia), PPI
   Access: PIV, PICC (placed [**3-19**])
   Code: Full code.  Ongoing discussion between liver team, MICU team and
   family given patient's declining status. Poor prognosis.

Based on the patient's 24-hour events and progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Hypoxia: The patient's oxygen requirement has decreased since Narcan administration, but the CXR shows a new infiltrate, which may indicate aspiration or edema. The patient's respiratory distress has worsened, and they may require intubation if not already intubated.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has trended up to 3.0, and the FENa is less than 1%, suggesting pre-renal failure due to hypovolemia or hepatorenal syndrome. The patient is receiving albumin infusions, which may help improve renal function.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has worsened, and they are likely experiencing hepatic encephalopathy and/or sepsis. The patient's hypernatremia may also be contributing to their altered mental status.
4. Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP): The patient has a history of SBP and is currently receiving treatment with Vanc/Zosyn. The patient's abdominal girth may be contributing to their respiratory distress.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely multifactorial, with possible causes including intrabdominal bleeding, low-grade GI bleed, and chronic disease.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia has improved, but they are still at risk for bleeding. The patient's liver failure and splenomegaly may be contributing to their thrombocytopenia.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is likely due to TF, and they require careful monitoring to avoid further electrolyte imbalances.
8. UTI: The patient's urine culture grew yeast, and they may require antifungal treatment if they decompensate.
9. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely due to liver failure and splenomegaly, and they require close monitoring and transfusions as needed.

The patient's condition is critical, and ongoing discussion between the liver team, MICU team, and family is necessary given the patient's poor prognosis.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also completed 9 days of
   vanc/zosyn for SBP thus it would be unlikely that pt developed a new
   PNA. However, VRE, fungal or other ESBL organism is a possibility. Her
   abdominal girth may also be contributing to decreased chest wall
   compliance. Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming more somnolent,
   able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved somewhat with
   Narcan. Satting in mid-90s on 4-5L O2 NC this morning.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema; will treat with
   Vanc/Zosyn again as this was a new event/infiltrate. Consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   - Will try to avoid intubation as it will likely be very difficult to
   extubated; however OK to intubate if necessary per family.
   - Avoid narcotics (none given since [**3-24**])
   - Repeat bladder pressure (15 this morning)
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improves after albumin infusion (5 infusions
   of 75g each so far), which argues against HRS. HRS treatment was
   discontinued and has been restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue octreotide, midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Increase lactulose and continue rifaxamin; quantify stool output to
   monitor response
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Also added Vanc. Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] with
   intention of switching to Cipro, however given new infiltrate on CXR
   along with increasing resp distress Vanc and Zosyn were re-started. No
   growth on culture of peritoneal fluid. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to
   remove 2.5L grossly bloody fluid.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn for now, but will switch to Cipro after PNA
   resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. Foley changed
   overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**].
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient decompensates, though no
   positive blood cultures
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Continue D5W at 100cc/hr for now, recheck lytes in afternoon.
   #.  H/o alcohol abuse. Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   # FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, TF per nutrition recs, ISS
   Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and
   thrombocytopenia), PPI
   Access: PIV, PICC (placed [**3-19**])
   Code: Full code.  Ongoing discussion between liver team, MICU team and
   family given patient's declining status. Poor prognosis.

Summary:

The patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcohol abuse and Tylenol overuse, who was transferred back to the MICU with worsening renal function, mental status, and respiratory distress. She has a history of SBP, and was treated with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam. She has also had a paracentesis and therapeutic paracentesis to remove grossly bloody fluid. She has been receiving albumin infusions, octreotide, and midodrine for her cirrhosis and portal vein thrombosis.

Current status:

* The patient has worsening hypoxia, with an oxygen requirement of 4-5L on nasal cannula.
* She has a new infiltrate on CXR, which may be due to aspiration or edema.
* Her mental status has worsened, with decreased responsiveness and somnolence.
* She has acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL.
* She has anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 8.9 g/dL.
* She has thrombocytopenia, with a platelet count of 52.
* She has hypernatremia, with a sodium level of 150 mmol/L.
* She has cirrhosis, with portal vein thrombosis and ascites.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening hypoxia and new infiltrate on CXR increase her risk of respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's worsening mental status and respiratory distress suggest a possibility of sepsis.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not treated promptly.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia increase her risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis and portal vein thrombosis increase her risk of liver failure.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may worsen if not treated promptly.

Plan:

* Continue vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam for the patient's new infiltrate on CXR.
* Consider antifungal treatment if the patient's respiratory distress worsens.
* Continue albumin infusions and octreotide for the patient's cirrhosis and portal vein thrombosis.
* Monitor the patient's electrolytes and adjust her fluid management accordingly.
* Consider intubation if the patient's respiratory distress worsens.
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a complex medical condition. The patient's chief complaint is abdominal and leg pain, which has been managed with ultram and simethicone. The patient's sodium levels have been corrected with D5W at 175cc/hr due to hypernatremia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 89 bpm, and blood pressure of 113/57 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with an SpO2 of 98% on 4-5L O2 NC. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring reveals a central venous pressure of 16 mmHg, and the patient is receiving fluid support.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of coagulopathy, anemia, and electrolyte imbalances. The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, with elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. The patient's renal function is compromised, with elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels.

The patient's medical history is significant for cirrhosis of the liver, alcohol-related, and hemolytic anemia. The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and acute pain.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's compromised respiratory status and underlying lung disease increase the risk of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's coagulopathy, anemia, and electrolyte imbalances increase the risk of sepsis.
3. Hepatorenal syndrome: The patient's liver dysfunction and compromised renal function increase the risk of hepatorenal syndrome.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels suggest acute kidney injury.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's history of aspiration pneumonia increases the risk of pneumonia.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy increases the risk of bleeding and hemorrhage.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia increases the risk of cardiovascular instability and respiratory compromise.
8. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte imbalances increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical condition requiring close monitoring and management. The patient's condition is at high risk for complications, and prompt recognition and treatment of these complications are necessary to prevent further deterioration.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back on [**3-25**] with worsening renal function,
   mental status, and respiratory distress.
   # Hypoxia:
   This AM in 98% on 6L NC.  CXR with question of multifocal PNA.
   Currently good coverage for HAP, although VRE, fungal or other ESBL
   organism is a possibility. Is now on new 8 day course of Vanc/Zosyn
   with initiation on [**2174-3-25**].  Overall very sensitive to narcotics and
   they should not be used due to extreme respiratory depression. Likely
   some component of impaired mechanics due to abdominal girth; however,
   correlation with O2 requirement and bladder pressures has not been
   drawn.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn with final day being [**2174-4-1**].
   - Liberate from supplemental oxygen as tolerated
   - Likely no need for additional bladder pressure measure as hypoxia
   persists despite reasonable pressures
   # Acute renal failure:
   Resolving with Cr of 0.8 this AM down from 1.9 on evening of [**2174-3-26**].
   Has been managed with albumin infusion (5 of 75g thus far) as well as
   octreotide and midodrine. Despite this, low likelihood of HRS.
   - Continue octreotide, midodrine for one additional day (last dose
   [**2174-3-29**])
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # Altered mental status:
   Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**], though overall more awake today than previous.
   Likely multifactorial with hepatic encephalopathy, SBP, uremia,
   hypernatremia. Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial process.
   - Increase lactulose to QID and continue rifaxamin; quantify stool
   output to monitor response.
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   # SBP:
   Has been exposed to many antibiotics at this point.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn for planned course ending [**2174-4-1**], but will
   switch to Cipro for suppression after that course is complete.
   # Hypernatremia:
   This in setting of hyponatremia initially. Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Continue D5W at 150cc/hr for now
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   # Anemia:
   Stable at approx 26 in last 4 days s/p aggressive FFP transfusions s/p
   intraabdominal bleeding. Cause likely multifactorial, biggest
   contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after paracenteses,
   superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Hemolysis unlikely
   to be contributing given past lab data. Also, has low grade GI bleed
   (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody).
   - Daily HCT check
   - Goal Hct is 21 if stable, will titrate transfusions if responding
   appropriately to blood.
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis:
   Patient w/ mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia,
   ascites, LE edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is
   likely secondary to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from
   chronic acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per
   patient and husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems
   acute due to no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD
   deferred by GI (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
   midodrine/octreotide 3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. Foley changed
   overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**].
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient decompensates, though no
   positive blood cultures
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of their condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcohol abuse and Tylenol overuse.
* She has a history of worsening renal function, mental status changes, and respiratory distress.
* She is currently receiving treatment for hypoxia, acute renal failure, altered mental status, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), hypernatremia, anemia, and portal vein thrombosis.
* She has a Foley catheter in place and is receiving antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals as needed.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Hypoxia: The patient's oxygen requirement is high, and there is a risk of worsening respiratory distress.
* Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and there is a risk of further deterioration in renal function.
* Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is fluctuating, and there is a risk of worsening encephalopathy.
* Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP): The patient has a history of SBP, and there is a risk of recurrence.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, and there is a risk of further worsening.
* Anemia: The patient has a low hemoglobin level, and there is a risk of further anemia.
* Portal Vein Thrombosis: The patient has a portal vein thrombosis, which may worsen her liver function and increase the risk of bleeding.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count, which may increase the risk of bleeding.
* UTI: The patient has a history of UTI, and there is a risk of recurrence.
* Liver Failure: The patient has cirrhosis and portal vein thrombosis, which may worsen her liver function and increase the risk of bleeding.

**Other:**

* The patient's code status is full code, and there is ongoing discussion between the liver team, MICU team, and family regarding her poor prognosis.
* The patient's disposition is ongoing ICU care, with possible transfer to the floor pending hepatology team evaluation.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities, including cirrhosis of the liver, hemolytic anemia, and a history of bleeding. They were admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, acute pneumonia, and aspiration pneumonia. The patient's condition has been stable, with improvements in oxygen saturation and blood pressure. However, they continue to require mechanical ventilation and have ongoing pain, hypernatremia, and coagulopathy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and there is a risk of further deterioration, including the development of ARDS.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen, leading to sepsis, septic shock, and multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's risk of aspiration is high, and there is a risk of further aspiration, which could lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, and death.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may worsen, leading to seizures, coma, and death.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage, and death.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further bleeding complications, decreased oxygen delivery, and organ dysfunction.
7. Hepatorenal syndrome: The patient's liver dysfunction may worsen, leading to further renal dysfunction, electrolyte imbalances, and death.
8. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's skin integrity may worsen, leading to further skin breakdown, infection, and death.
9. Infection: The patient is at high risk of developing further infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and sepsis.
10. Bleeding: The patient is at high risk of bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage, and death.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-inch tall individual admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of abdominal and leg pain, and was more alert and verbal during the 24-hour period. The patient's sodium level in the evening was 150, prompting the administration of D5W at 175cc/hr to correct hypernatremia. The patient's oxygen saturation levels are in the mid-90s with 4-5L O2 NC. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 89 bpm, and blood pressure of 113/57 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support consists of nasal cannula oxygen delivery.

The patient's physical examination reveals jaundice, sclera icteric, oropharynx dry, and distended abdomen without tenderness or rebound. The patient has bilateral 3+ LE pitting edema and is warm and well-perfused.

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.5-12.9 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.9-10.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 52-76 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.0-1.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 29-47 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: sodium 172 mg/dL, potassium 3.6 mEq/L, chloride 100 mg/dL, and bicarbonate 24.9%

The patient has a diagnosis of respiratory failure, acute pneumonia, aspiration, hypernatremia, coagulopathy, anemia, acute electrolyte and fluid disorder, and impaired skin integrity.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Pneumonia progression: The patient's pneumonia diagnosis may worsen, leading to respiratory failure and increased risk of mortality.
2. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels may continue to rise, leading to dehydration, seizures, or even death.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulation disorder may worsen, leading to bleeding complications or increased risk of hemorrhage.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, or decreased tolerance to physical activity.
5. Hepatorenal syndrome: The patient's liver disease may worsen, leading to kidney failure and increased risk of mortality.
6. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's skin integrity may worsen, leading to increased risk of infection, bleeding, or skin breakdown.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's distended abdomen and anemia may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and anemia may increase the risk of sepsis, a life-threatening condition characterized by systemic inflammation and organ dysfunction.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental
   status and respiratory distress.
   # Hypoxia: CXR with possible multifocal pna, but has had decreased
   oxygen requirement since narcan. She also completed 9 days of
   vanc/zosyn for SBP thus it would be unlikely that pt developed a new
   PNA. However, VRE, fungal or other ESBL organism is a possibility. Her
   abdominal girth may also be contributing to decreased chest wall
   compliance. Worsening hypoxia overnight [**3-25**], becoming more somnolent,
   able to maintain O2 sats > 90% with 100 FiO2. Improved somewhat with
   Narcan. Satting in mid-90s on 4-5L O2 NC this morning.
   - CXR shows new infiltrate
 aspiration vs edema; will treat with
   Vanc/Zosyn again as this was a new event/infiltrate. Consider VRE
   coverage as well.
   - Will try to avoid intubation as it will likely be very difficult to
   extubated; however OK to intubate if necessary per family.
   - Avoid narcotics (none given since [**3-24**])
   - Repeat bladder pressure (15 this morning)
   - Wean supplemental O2 as tolerated for goal O2 sat >92%
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trended up to peak of 3.0 previously. FENa
   <1%, thus pre-renal due to hypovolemia (large stool output) or
   hepatorenal syndrome. Cr improves after albumin infusion (5 infusions
   of 75g each so far), which argues against HRS. HRS treatment was
   discontinued and has been restarted over the last several days.
   - Continue octreotide, midodrine per Liver
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # Altered mental status. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**]. Likely hepatic
   encephalopathy and SBP. Also persistently hypernatremic which is likely
   contributing to her AMS.  Has been receiving free water and Na is
   stable and mildly elevated.  Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial
   process.  Appears a bit more altered this morning, but is still
   responsive to voice.
   - Increase lactulose and continue rifaxamin; quantify stool output to
   monitor response
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   # SBP: Received Unasyn x 3 days at OSH for SBP Prophylaxis. Started
   Ceftriaxone upon arrival here. S/P diagnostic paracentesis - Second tap
   showed incr WBC with L shift, changed CTX to Zosyn on [**3-15**], per
   informal ID recs.  Also added Vanc. Vanc/Zosyn d/c
d [**3-23**] with
   intention of switching to Cipro, however given new infiltrate on CXR
   along with increasing resp distress Vanc and Zosyn were re-started. No
   growth on culture of peritoneal fluid. Therapeutic para done [**3-20**] to
   remove 2.5L grossly bloody fluid.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn for now, but will switch to Cipro after PNA
   resolves
   - Recheck bladder pressure
   # Anemia: Stable after aggressive FFP transfusions. Cause likely
   multifactorial, biggest contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after
   paracenteses, superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Also
   has low grade GI bleed (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody). Unlikely that
   the patient has DIC/hemolysis, since lab data underwhelming - low retic
   index, direct bilirubinemia, normal LDH, normal haptoglobin. GSurgery/
   transplant surgery recs: no OR.
   - Will hold off on further FFP transfusions for now
   - Daily HCT check
   - Will treat supportively with blood products. Goal Hct is 21 if
   stable, will titrate transfusions if responding appropriately to blood.
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis: Patient w/
   mild transaminitis (stable) with stable thrombocytopenia, ascites, LE
   edema, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated INR.  This is likely secondary
   to cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic
   acetaminophen use.  Currently not drinking for 1 month per patient and
   husband prior to admission . Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to
   no collateral flow in the portal circulation on CT. EGD deferred by GI
   (feels anemia more likely due to hemolysis). D/c
d midodrine/octreotide
   3/25 per liver.
   - Follow liver enzymes
 bilirubin stable and elevated
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide as above
   - minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate liver recs, will continue to have ongoing discussion with
   liver team regarding prognosis and likelihood of recovery.
   # UTI: Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. Foley changed
   overnight [**Date range (1) 5037**].
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient decompensates, though no
   positive blood cultures
   #  Thrombocytopenia. Improved. Likely secondary to liver failure and
   splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret with
   liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   # Hypernatremia after initial hyponatremia: Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Mix meds in D5W
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Continue D5W at 100cc/hr for now, recheck lytes in afternoon.

Summary:

The patient is a 44-year-old female with cirrhosis, presumed secondary to alcohol abuse and Tylenol overuse, who is status post a 2-week stay in the MICU and is transferred back with worsening renal function, mental status, and respiratory distress. She has a history of SBP, and the current diagnosis is likely VRE, fungal, or other ESBL organism. The patient has acute renal failure, anemia, cirrhosis, hyperbilirubinemia, portal vein thrombosis, UTI, and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxia: The patient's worsening respiratory distress and new infiltrate on CXR may lead to further hypoxia, which could be life-threatening.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's Cr trended up to a peak of 3.0, and FENa < 1% suggests pre-renal failure due to hypovolemia or hepatorenal syndrome. Continued worsening of renal function could lead to further complications.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is likely due to hepatic encephalopathy and SBP. Further worsening of AMS could lead to increased risk of complications.
4. SBP: The patient has a history of SBP and is currently receiving treatment with Vanc/Zosyn. Further episodes of SBP could lead to worsening of her condition.
5. UTI: The patient has a positive U/A, and the culture growing yeast may indicate a fungal infection. If left untreated, this could lead to further complications.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely secondary to liver failure and splenomegaly. Continued bleeding could lead to further complications.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is likely due to TF. Continued electrolyte imbalance could lead to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue treatment for hypoxia with Vanc/Zosyn and consider VRE coverage.
2. Monitor and manage acute renal failure with continued albumin infusions and octreotide.
3. Continue treatment for altered mental status with lactulose and rifaxamin.
4. Continue treatment for SBP with Vanc/Zosyn and consider switching to Cipro once PNA resolves.
5. Monitor and manage UTI with antifungal treatment if the patient decompensates.
6. Monitor and manage thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions as needed.
7. Monitor and manage hypernatremia with continued D5W and free water flushes.
8. Continue liver enzyme monitoring and discuss prognosis and likelihood of recovery with the liver team.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 44 year old female with cirrhosis presumed secondary to
   alcohol abuse and tylenol overuse who is status post a 2 week stay in
   the MICU and is transferred back on [**3-25**] with worsening renal function,
   mental status, and respiratory distress.
   # Hypoxia:
   This AM in 98% on 6L NC.  CXR with question of multifocal PNA.
   Currently good coverage for HAP, although VRE, fungal or other ESBL
   organism is a possibility. Is now on new 8 day course of Vanc/Zosyn
   with initiation on [**2174-3-25**].  Overall very sensitive to narcotics and
   they should not be used due to extreme respiratory depression. Likely
   some component of impaired mechanics due to abdominal girth; however,
   correlation with O2 requirement and bladder pressures has not been
   drawn.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn with final day being [**2174-4-1**].
   - Liberate from supplemental oxygen as tolerated
   - Likely no need for additional bladder pressure measure as hypoxia
   persists despite reasonable pressures
   # Acute renal failure:
   Resolving with Cr of 0.8 this AM down from 1.9 on evening of [**2174-3-26**].
   Has been managed with albumin infusion (5 of 75g thus far) as well as
   octreotide and midodrine. Despite this, low likelihood of HRS. Despite
   improving Cr, BUN remains elevated to 100 this AM.
   - Research further causes of isolated uremia
   - Continue octreotide, midodrine for one additional day (last dose
   [**2174-3-29**])
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - Renally dose meds
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   # Altered mental status:
   Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 282**], though overall more awake today than previous.
   Likely multifactorial with hepatic encephalopathy, SBP, uremia,
   hypernatremia. Head CT on [**3-13**] neg for acute intracranial process.
   - Increase lactulose to QID and continue rifaxamin; quantify stool
   output to monitor response.
   - Treat hypernatremia as below
   # SBP:
   Has been exposed to many antibiotics at this point.
   - Continue Vanc/Zosyn for planned course ending [**2174-4-1**], but will
   switch to Cipro for suppression after that course is complete.
   # Hypernatremia:
   This in setting of hyponatremia initially. Initial hypoNa likely
   secondary to ascites and LE edema. Suspect pt became hyperNa due to TF.
   - Cont free water flushes to 300cc Q4hrs
   - Continue D5W at 150cc/hr for now
   - [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   # Anemia:
   Stable at approx 26 in last 4 days s/p aggressive FFP transfusions s/p
   intraabdominal bleeding. Cause likely multifactorial, biggest
   contributor being intrabdominal bleeding after paracenteses,
   superimposed on baseline anemia of chronic disease. Hemolysis unlikely
   to be contributing given past lab data. Also, has low grade GI bleed
   (guaiac pos, not grossly bloody).
   - Daily HCT check
   - Goal Hct is 21 if stable, will titrate transfusions if responding
   appropriately to blood.
   # Cirrhosis / hyperbilirubinemia / portal vein thrombosis:
   Liver enzymes stable elevation, Tbili with stable elevation. INR
   increasing daily and is 2.8 today.  This is likely secondary to
   cirrhosis from alcoholism with exacerbation from chronic acetaminophen
   use. Portal vein thrombosis seems acute due to no collateral flow in
   the portal circulation on CT.
   - Follow liver enzymes and bilirubin daily
   - Continue midodrine/octreotide for one additional day as above
   - Minimize non-essential meds
   - Appreciate onoing hepatology input.
   - Transfer to hepatology team later today if they agree with eval that
   she is stable for floor care
   # UTI:
   Positive U/A on [**3-23**], culture growing yeast. Foley changed overnight
   [**Date range (1) 5037**].
   - Consider antifungal treatment if patient decompensates, though no
   positive blood cultures
   #  Thrombocytopenia.
   Imiproving from 30s to 76 this AM. Likely secondary to liver failure
   and splenomegaly.  Evaluation for TTP and DIC difficult to interpret
   with liver failure.  Rare schistocytes on smear with elevated PTT, low
   fibrinogen, and direct hyperbilirubinemia.  However, LDH normal,
   arguing against TMA. E. coli O175:H7 neg argues against TTP/HUS.
   - Follow plt count and transfuse if plt < 10 or as needed to control
   bleeding
   #.  H/O alcohol abuse:
   Completed 5 days of high dose thiamine.
   - Continue multivitamins, folate
   - SW consult when mental status improves
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Fibersource HN (Full) - [**2174-3-27**] 01:00 PM 50 mL/hour

   DVT:  Pneumoboots (no HSQ given elevated INR and thrombocytopenia)

   Code status: FULL CODE - Ongoing discussion between liver team, MICU
   team and family given patient's declining status. Poor prognosis.
   Disposition: Ongoing ICU care this AM with possible call-out to floor
   this evening pending hepatology team eval.
